posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pandoro is good but it’s boring, it’s just a soft brioche that tastes like vanilla and butter, you’d be happier with a fresh bakery croissant with a more complex texture and layers with an exterior crust that crunches.

Panettone, on the other hand, is the gentleman’s choice because it’s so rich and smells like heaven, there are flavours hidden in the bites, you can find the raisin and then a piece of candied orange in the next one, or both, and the same goes for other flavours, also the glaze or “topping”
some style of panettone have makes sure that you won’t get bored at all while eating the slice, and the airy interior makes up for a moist and soft experience.

In other words, pandoro is for kids who loves simpler things, panettone is for grown ups.

>>18731581
>We shouldn't mess with the classic panettone – the idea that everything has to be new saddens me
>Panettone has been ruined by poor variations including prosecco, salted caramel, and savoury cheese flavours

>There are two things about the wave of adulterated panettones – featuring novelty flavours including everything from tiramisu to peach bellini and even parmesan and black pepper – that I strongly resent. The classic recipe and its original ingredients – flour, butter, raisins and candied citrus among them – were intended to make the cake last for some time. It was created to transport easily and takes days to make, for the dough to prove, but can last for weeks. It is pure.

>Modern technology, which enables producers to pump just about anything into panettone, has led to an ill-formed cake with an ingredients list packed with additives that are far from conducive to your health.

>Secondly, the idea that everything has to be new, or reinvented with new flavours, saddens me. Of course food – and our attitude towards it – changes through the ages, but just sometimes in life we ought to just stop and enjoy something that has been around for centuries. If something still excites our senses and makes our heart sing after so long, we ought to ask the question why.

>Panettone has been a Christmas tradition my whole life. We didn’t have much money when I was growing up and we didn’t have an oven capable of making one, but we would buy one – it was our treat, a Christmas cake only sold at Christmas time. I loved the airy texture, the generous amount of raisins and chunks of candied peel studded throughout, and would happily pick off the sugar crystals from the top to eat, to the annoyance of my mother. She insisted there had to be enough left for everyone to enjoy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18731591
>Its flavours were perfect. These days, they have been amplified so much they taste plastified, far too sugary. It deflects from what a great panettone should taste like. I’ve even made them myself over the years, none of them terribly successful as this is a hard cake to make – just look at that dough, its lightness, the glorious holes. Even more reason to respect the skill and specialist equipment of its traditional expert bakers.

>Consider panettone like you would a beautiful sourdough loaf – you wouldn’t want to change anything about such a brilliant bread. With loaves – and with panettone – if you change just a few ingredients the result will not stand the test of time.

>By all means toast slices of panettone and spread them with butter or jam, or turn them into a pudding topped with custard or (my favourite) molten chocolate. But prosecco panettone, salted caramel, savoury cheese versions? These one-hit wonders will never rival the real deal.

Cakettone recipe:

>2 eggs
>1/2 cup sugar
>1 1/2 cup flour
>1/4 cup oil
>1/4 cup milk
>1/2 cup raisins
>1/2 cup candied peel
>1 TBSP panettone extract
>1 TBSP cake yeast
>1 cup cream
Icing
>1 cup icing sugar
>1 1/2 TBSP milk
>fruits to decorate

Beat eggs, and sugar until frothy. Add oil, milk and cream and beat. Add flour little at the time and mix. Add extract and cake levener and mix. Add ruits and mix. Cook in buttered and flour cake tin until done. Let cool, add icing, add fruit to decorate.

>>18738043
Eosiniphilic Esophagitis sufferer here, I can't have wheat or dairy (long story). I have used both tapioca and coconut flour to make pancakes. They're both ok.

You don't want to add tapioca directly to boiling water. Slowly mix water to dry tapioca until it becomes crumbly like bleau cheese. Then put a large handful of the crumbs onto a lightly oiled pan and press down with a spatula until they fry. At this point they will stick together into one sheet and you can flip it and fry the other side. Look up "tapioca pancake" on youtube for a demo. They do this in south america its a real dish. Only downside is that pure tapioca pancakes have a rubbery texture.

For a classic crispy pancake texture, you can add coconut flour to tapioca flour. This will require more water since coconut flour absorbs water like a bitch. Make a thick slurry like regular pancake batter and just fry that shit like normal.

Warning, NEVER add sugar to tapioca flour or it will form am extremely sticky inedible crust and will be a pain in the ass to remove from the pan.

Sucks you can't have rice, I basically live off white rice and beef.

Merry Christmas from one autoimmune disease sufferer to another.

>>18739530
If you do make the recipe in >>18739366 , make sure to save some of the starch in case you add too much water, which is very easy to do.

You could also try making these baked "biscuits" (they're usually made with eggs though and I've never tried them egg-free)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6iK500XQcCo
I'll translate (or localize, rather) the ingredients list, just do what she does and adjust the ingredients to get a similar consistency.
>1 cup tapioca starch
>1/2 cup + 2 tbsp boiling water
>1 tsp salt
>2 tbsp vegetable oil or other fat of your choice
Scalding the starch is very important, you mentioned you made something similar but that seems like a lot of water to too little flour, whereas for a dough like this (which is very similar to pão de queijo) it's supposed to be much firmer and you have to knead it until the lumps are incorporated.
You can also deep fry them instead.

Also, does your flour have a particular smell to it? Here in Hueland tapioca starch is sold either fermented or unfermented. The "cheesy" flavor >>18739580 is talking about is for the fermented variety only and imo it's very tasty. Those biscuits are made with fermented starch, so if you're using plain starch they won't really taste much of anything but they'll still have a nice texture so you can pair them with whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18737346
Nope. You would think so. It's heavily salted lamb meat, so you have to soak it in water for 24-36 hours and then you steam it for 3-5 hours until it's fork tender. You either put some wooden sticks or almond potatoes in the bottom of the pan for the steaming. It renders out an amazing fatty stock which you can use for sauce and if you do the potato version they will still be firm even though they have been boiled for 3-5 hours due to the salt and fat.

At the end you put them in the oven for 10 mins just to get a bit of color. The Rutabaga and carrot mash is sweet and creamy, balancing out the fatty, salty meat. On the side you have a shot of akevit to help against the fat.

>>18739559
Alcohol taxes make malt liquor pointless in Australia and I doubt people would like it anyway even if it was viable. Reason is there's an alcohol tax which is based around alcohol volume that would make malt liquor too expensive for people to bother buying.
Instead of cheep beer, in Australia we use cask wine because there's a different tax on wine that becomes much lower than beer when buying cheap cask wine. You can get a 4L box of wine with ~30 standard drinks for $9 AUD but the cheapest ratshit beers with an equivalent alcohol level would cost 5 times as much. If you don't like wine buy want cheaper options then you just go buy large bottles of gin or vodka & mix it, or Mercury Cider where you can get cans with double the alcohol most beers contain without costing too much more.

Bugs are not a viable alternative protein source for humans for several reasons. First, the human body cannot digest chitin, the main component of insect exoskeletons. Second, bugs are not a very efficient source of protein, requiring more food (in the form of insects) to convert into protein than other animals such as chickens

There are a number of reasons why the human body cannot digest chitin. Chitin is a complex polysaccharide that is not broken down by human digestive enzymes. Additionally, chitin is not a good source of nutrition for humans, as it is not a good source of essential amino acids. Finally, chitin can actually have a negative impact on human health, as it can bind to and kill beneficial gut bacteria

Bugs are also not a very efficient source of protein. In order to obtain usable protein from bugs, humans would need to eat a large number of them. This is because insects are mostly made up of exoskeleton, which is indigestible for humans. Additionally, insects have a very low conversion rate of food to protein, meaning that more insects would need to be eaten to obtain the same amount of protein as from other animals

Finally, bugs are a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions. A study published in the journal Science found that a diet rich in insects would result in higher emissions of methane and nitrous oxide, two of the most potent greenhouse gases. The study found that the emissions from a diet of insects were about double those of a typical livestock-based diet.

Source:

>>18731754
>It's those billboards
There's an interesting story about that, actually.
As I understand it, back in 2000 there was legislation to try and limit the number of new billboards that could be built on the highways and interstates.
"New" being the operative word. Advertisers fought back by pre-emptively erecting a bunch of new billboards in hopes they'd get grandfathered in.

But after that, the bill failed and their would-be monopoly crumbled. There was a massive surplus with low demand, so advertising costs plummeted to pennies in the more rural areas of the state.

That's why you see cases where a church or a liquor store manages to buy 6 in a row. They're literally Bargain Bin Billboards.

Actually: ham is usually a scam. Most of the cheap ones aren't actually smoked. They are just injected with chemical slop to make it taste like smoke (for those who can taste it). Usually loaded with water weight to cut corners.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18721888
>I'm going to cook a prime rib dinner for my family on christmas, what are some good sides to go with it?
Took advantage of the Publix prices last 2 years in a row and got a 4rib portion.
Think British, really.
Get a nice trifle bowl and your trifle laced with sherry soaking, macerating the berries and boozy, get it good and cold. This is your dessert of choice.
For nice apps, anything seafood is popular, from an old fashioned cold shrimp cocktail to some stone crabs. For sides, you want a seasonal soup course, or a nice salad course, your pick Gorgonzola on that salad or cheese tray. It's pretty chilly this year, so the steakhouse soups are okay, like french onion. Remember you will want some horseradish w/ sourcream, lemon and parsley to make it special.
I like a good pan gravy which is going to happen with coffee in the pan and a covered roaster, so will want mashed potatoes with that roast beef gravy (versus roasted). Fancymode, twice bake some big potatoes. Bake up your tray of veggies from mushrooms to winter squash, brussels sprouts, mix em! or like tomato halves with herbs and breadcrumbs. A casserole like creamed baby onions or creamed spinach to add another side. If your oven is crowded, you rest that roast under foil, and reheat the gravy, that's all. Use your burner to steam some green beans w/red onions.
Pro-mode is yorkshire pudding. I am a sucker for nice rolls too.
MUST HAVE, a nice raspberry jello mold with cranberries and oranges. Or some kind of grandma style picalilli. It just goes to balance your plate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
red potatoes
wash and scrub
cut into 8ths, 12ths, 16ths, or 20ths depending on size
put into large mixing bowl
add olive oil, salt, pepper, garlic powder, optionally paprika
Toss to evenly coat
dump out onto foiled oven tray
bake in oven at like 400f for like 40m

You can try this in smaller batches to figure out your spice ratio preferences. I typically use only a little salt, a a good amount of garlic powder, and enough pepper that my family tells me to make them with less pepper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18737181
There's only one commercially produced anymore and it's in this state. It is really strong and pungent, but the whole makes up for the sum of its parts. Everything has to be so over-the-top that they cancel each other out. Very rye bread (pumpernickel), very strong mustard, fresh red onions, and smoked spread liverwurst. Preferably with a dark beer.
Had a friend who fell asleep watching a movie while we were making it, and I gave it to him half passed out. While he was eating it he seemed fine, but then a piece fell out on his lap and he went to eat it. He immediately woke up and said what the fuck is? The individual ingredient is overpowering, but the ensemble kind of cancels each other out.

posts.com:
it turned out terrible and its my fault. rather than the usual ham, my mother asked me to cook some steaks they had in their freezer vacuum sealed for months. i am used to cooking thick boneless ny strips where i do a reverse sear in a very hot oven to get a nice 120 degree pink medium rare. these were cheap bone in thin ny strips. let dry brine in the fridge for 2 days. i got a great pan sear on them, when done they were at around 108 degrees. had i just taken them out, drained the oil, and made the butter+rosemary+garlic to baste then let them rest 10 minutes, they would have been great. but no, since i am so used to a reverse sear, sure, put it in the 400 degree oven with the brussels sprouts and potatoes for a few minutes, fucking idiot.

the steaks were borderline well done, if not well done. completely fucking gray. no fucking flavor. practically inedible. i was pissed off for the entire meal. i cant believe i did that fucking shit. ive never had a steak that bad. usually with the thick ones i would get so paranoid about overcooking that i would cook them basically rare. then i do this shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: So I am high as a kite eating some leftover meatballs from a christmas eve dinner, they didn't have gravy on them or anything, and I was gonna have ice cream after. and then I was like, icecream and meatballs, just rolls off the tongue right? and I laughed but then I was like, well hang on a tick here, I might be onto somethin. We've got sweet, and savory, wet and dry, warm and cold, everything else is just details when you get down to it, right? And so I think to myself, people eat chocolate covered bacon, or bacon bits in some novelty ice cream deserts. This could work. There's bread crumbs in the meatballs, that's kind of gonna give it a bread pudding and ice cream vibe, thats a real thing. So I says to myself, yer room mates are gone, no one's gonna know except those deer outside my window. You only live once, its the last meatball, if it doesn't work out not a big deal. But what an opportunity. Who knows how long I've been sleeping on something like this. and so I try it yeah? phenomenal, absolutely worth it. It's not just good, it's so good that people need to know, right? Just not anyone I actually know IRL, but the public, they gotta know. Someone needs to know how good this is before I move on. And here we are, you and I. I know what you're wondering, it was Raspberry chocolate chip ice cream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

at a point in my life my wealthy Baptist grandmother on my mothers side came to me and said she would purchase a Chic-fil-A franchise for me to manage.
I began to research what a Chic-fil-A franchise purchase would require.
Apparently it is one of the cheapest initial franchise investments at only 10k
But also one of the lowest acceptance rate's
Out of 10,000 applicants they would only accept around 100.
They are looking for a very specific type of person to manage their franchises
I'm not gonna say that Chick-fil-A is a cult
But there is a very strong correlation between their corporate ideologies and the Southern Baptist Convention of churches.
Their distribution of franchises also correlates strongly with Baptist churches in America.
I don't think there is anything wrong with a particular corporation in having an ideological culture built in to the business model, but consumers should be informed on what that ideology is.

>light beer pill
It's not healthy, but if you can make it work it's the lesser of a lot of evils. I couldn't do it, though. I'd either drink 30 light beers or I'd give up after a few and go get some malt liquor.

For some people drinking is running a marathon; for me it's the 100-yard dash. Once I get a little bit of alcohol in me, I feel an irresistible compulsion to drink a lot very fast until smashed. It wasn't that way in my first few years of drinking, but it has been for the last twenty. So I could never make any harm reduction work.

As for your waiting to stop, I guess you've decided alcohol is adding something worthwhile to your life. Nothing wrong with that, if it's true. Those first few years of drinking were awfully sweet for me, so if you're still getting that I can understand why you would want to salvage it rather than cut it out entirely.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18737309
Staying hydrated while drinking, a glass of water every other drink. Fructose turns ethanol to sucrose and you can process alcohol 30% faster if you drink the goysyrup. Cutting yourself off and getting rehydrated for a few hours before you pass out. Taking 2 advil before bed lessens the inflammation and you sleep better and have less of a headache the next day. Weed also has a similar effect.

The problem is that it's a one-two punch of toxins, dehydration and inflammation. You can lessen it but moderation and not drinking past 8pm is the only real way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18737309
>>18737440
Any nsaid (advil, tylenol, etc.) can increase the risk of liver scarring or fatty liver disease. It's worth it if you get fucked up once in a blue moon, but if you live your life like this, skip the advil. Same basic advice for bumping up the fructose in/with your drinks - plus processing alcohol faster can actually make the withdrawals worse.

Something like pedialyte that's got glucose, fructose and a few different salts to bump up your electrolytes (the same ones plants crave) can help immensely. Caffeine (or cocaine) can help mask some of the symptoms and brain fog. A greasy breakfast combined with the caffeine can help you shit, which is mostly a psychosomatic relief at this point, but will still make you feel better. And advil/tylenol can cut the headache - take with an extra glass of water.

>tl;dr
You can treat the symptoms of a hangover, or try to prevent them, but not cure the hangover after the fact.

Specifically seven is italoamerican, yes, but we just eat any ol' fish and in no specific number. How the fish is prepared and which fish it is varies family to family and/or by simple availability/what looks good at the market.

Here's mine OP, inb4 I get mogged for putting corn in my chili.

INGREDIENTS:

FRESH
5-6lb of ground beef
1 ½ large onions
4 large bell peppers

CANNED
3 28oz cans of whole peeled San Marzano tomatoes
2 14oz cans of dark red kidney beans
1 14oz can of whole kernel corn
1 7oz can of chipotle peppers

WET INGREDIENTS
2 tbsp of honey
1 tbsp mustard
2 tsp Worcestershire
2 tsp soy sauce
2 tsp fish sauce
fat/oil for frying

SPICES
5 tbsps. chili powder
Habanero/cayenne powder
1 tbsp paprika
1 tbsp cumin
1 tbsp Chicken Bullion
½ tsp garlic powder

OPTIONAL GARNISHES
Sour cream
Crackers, corn chips, tortilla chips
Avocado
Chives or parsley
Shredded Cheese


Also why yes the chicken bullion I use is indeed Knorr™ brand

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18738817
Pho sounds like a great idea for my duck bones/giblets. Thanks op. These were some tips in a soup thread a few anons shared that I saved

Always keep it around a low simmer. When it gets up to a boil is when it gets cloudy. You can roast things in the oven for a different flavor. Get a good sense of what works for stock (parsnips, onions, celery) and what doesn't (cauliflower, potatoes). Look up recipes but know you can just use them as references. Make your life easier and put the peppercorns, etc. in a tea bag, the kind used for loose leaf. Also, you can save scraps in the freezer. Mushroom stems are one of my favorite things to add.

literally just boil meat and aromatics, skim the protein skuzz off the top as it cooks, and strain it with a fine mesh sieve at the end

Very lightly coat your bones and veg in a couple of tablespoons of tomato paste, roast or brown them in a pan for deeper flavor, go easy on the salt, and don't go too nuts with fennel unless you REALLY dig the anise flavor. Mushrooms also make a nice addition

Roast your bones/trimmings and vegetables, separately, on two parchment-lined sheet trays - at 425F until they are as brown as you want them especially the chicken bones. The vegetables will likely cook faster than the chicken bones so they are on a separate tray.


Gravy recipe:
Cook some flour in the pan juices. If you don't have enough pan juice and the flour isn't wet enough add some butter. Then gradually add water while whisking. Season with some salt and pepper and some soy sauce. Simple as.
I usually spatchcock a chicken and roast it on a bed of rosemary and garlic, and cover it in a butter rub. Then when it comes gravy time there's some rosemary leaves left in the pan and I'll leave a few cloves of garlic which break up under the whisk.

- Rice
- Lard
- pepper
- salt

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
yeah OP this shit sucks. the "until done" shit persists in a lot of recipes largely because explaining what that means takes a lot of words, and once you've been cooking for a while you learn by sense what it means. a lot of recipes also do a bad job emphasizing the purpose of each step which leads to newfriends not really understanding why they're doing certain things.

i really recommend following recipes from food youtubers for a while so you can see what the food looks like at each step. they have to pad video length for ads, so they also do a better job of explaining what they're going for in each step. chef john (food wishes) and babish are pretty good for this when you know absolutely nothing. babish kinda just adopts all his recipes from chef john, america's test kitchen, and j kenji lopez, but because he's fairly inexperienced himself he emphasizes the kind of stuff you need to look out for at your expertise level (retard)

stovetop burners all cook at different heats, the numbers are only relative to your stove. you're just going to have to learn the minute differences between your stove and others' generally. everything in the kitchen is approximate, so you're just gonna have to use the cook times as a rough guideline and learn to spot that "until done" stuff we talked about above. you can only really figure it out by cooking a bunch

sorry but you are just kinda retarded for the cups thing bro. get a measuring cup or something. i have a bunch of little cups/containers that are exactly 1 cup that use to quickly scoop out whatever i need in that quantity and eyeball half/three-quarters/etc.

cook some easy recipes like minestrone, mac and cheese, and pasta sauce and you'll figure some stuff out. it's easier than it seems, you just need to build the knowledge of how food changes through the process of cooking.

A cup is 8 US fluid oz, medium heat is not low, not high, my stove has settings 1-9 with 1 being the lowest and 9, being the highest. I can cook a medium done steak in 7-8 minutes on setting 5, which I consider to be medium heat.

>>18731213
Here's the dirty little secret about cooking : It is not an exact science.
Except for baked goods or very specific things like roux, you're not gonna ruin a dish by using 20% more or less of any given ingredient called for in a recipe. Going for the exact measurement down to the gram or the milliliter is absolutely not necessary, it's just a useful approximation of what you should try to aim for, which is helpful for novices who never cooked anything in their whole lives and are too inexperienced to know they shouldn't put 10 tablespoons of cayenne pepper in their stew.
At the end of the day, using 200ml of tomato paste instead of 250ml isn't gonna turn a delicious dish into something inedible. Cooking something on medium instead of medium-low isn't gonna incinerate whatever's in your pan, etc.
Plus, not following exact instruction gives you the flexibility to tweak the dish to your own tastes. For exemple, whenever a recipe calls for a 1/1/1 or 1/1/2 ratio of celery/carrots/onions, I always do 1/2/3 instead because that's how I like my mirepoix.
Cooking should be an enjoyable, zen experience. No need to turn the process into some sort of autistic hard science. It's not necessary, and you'll end up with tasty food either way.

Anyway, you should only eat cheese from Vermont, NH, Mass, NY, Washington, Oregon, andn California. Anything produced deeper inland is strictly McDonands grade trash.

>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

>ordering no salt fries at mcdicks to "force them to make a fresh batch"
I hate this "lifehack" with an undying fucking passion. I am convinced people doing this is 100% to blame for fast food restaurants never salting their fries appropriately any more. Instead of getting nice salty fries with salt melted right into the oil as it dries on the surface of the fries you get bland saltless fries that you have to try to add salt to when they're already dry and cool, it doesn't taste the same. On the plus side, this phenomenon has reduced my consumption of fast food in general, but I wish I could still get a nice well-salted order of fries now and again and I blame those retarded lifehack fucks for permanently ruining it.

I am in my thirties now and am still fucked with it, dr said a bug went through my system emitting goasses that paralized parts of my stomach and intestines and the damage was so bad that not even a pasemaker can fix it.

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

>>18713841
bad hummus...
was camping with friends and had cooked a big celebration dinner for something--Steaks, hobo pack veggies and baked potatoes on the campfire...all fresh and from scratch except for 1 thing--some hummus that LOOKED and TASTED ok, maybe a little sour, but not really OFF.
Just as we'd finished cleaning up,(quickly, as a big summer storm was rolling in,) the storm hit with a vengence--big fucking banger of a thunderstorm too.
laying down in my tent with the driving rain pelting the fly, All of a sudden, I got that feeling--you know, the tight, almost battery acid tasting tightness right behind your jaw? I knew I had seconds to get out for the inevitable technicolor yawn...
Wouldn't you know? the fucking zipper gets stuck, off track, a good 3-5 minutes of fucking around with it in the best of circumstances--and that rain is fucking coming down in BUCKETS.
PANIC....Sheer panic sets in, I can't hold my gorge back any longer...
I fucking ripped the tent door open at the zipper and stumbled out into the now hammering rain, puking all that excellent dinner we'd just eaten in all directions as I staggered through the muddy forest to get further away from the tent, so I didn't have a pool of vomit sitting right outside of it. I spent the next 15 minutes on all fours, purging my entire being until I could do nothing but dry heave with sheets of water coming down all around me...
I was fine in the morning, and was able to fix the tent zipper so that it would NEVER LOCK UP ON ME AGAIN...but that had to be the worst.
Only one almost as bad was burning through half a case of little kings playing the "minute game"I made good friends with the snails that night as I crawled around in the dewy grass under the full moon...good times.
btw, when I checked that Godforsaken CURSED HUMMUS the next morning, it was actually bubbling--so I know that was the culprit.
I still like hummus though, even if I always give it the hairy-eyeball if it's store-bought.

I had two cube steaks with some mushrooms, some cheese, a little jerkey for a snack later, then sipped on some bourbon before bed. I ended up eating a whole round of banana nut bread. If it helped, it helped, so I just fucking ate it.

here's full recipe as promised:

. 750 grams for 4 people. fresh acnhovis or sardines, small-ish size, like you can eat fully in 3 bites tops
. . without head or fish-bones (here you can ask the women on the fish section to cut them like that for you, or do it yourself at home)

. wash them and put the in a bowl covered with the following
. . half a glass of water
. . half glass of wine vinegar (can use the regular one or modena doesn't matter)
. . salt, chopped garlig, oregano
. . . cover the sardines in the bowl with this mix for 1h (minimum) or 1 day (optimal) (you can put them in the fridge no problemo)
. drain the sardines a bit, cover in all purpose flour and fry them until golden color
. . . das le it
. . . . (pic is some random pic that resembles the final result)

posts.com:
My little bro bought a metric fuckton of shit from a local international food market, and got all sorts of shit and gave it to me as a Christmas gift.
This was one of the items.
Shizuren Beef Instant Noodles.

I actually was off-put by some of the packets I was putting into the cup cause there was like 7 of them and none of them had any English saying what the fuck I was about to eat.
It smelled curry, other spices, and then there was this meat that I prayed to god was just sardines.
Judging by the illustrations, I just opted to microwave a hot cup of water in a coffee mug for three minutes and just dump it into the cup itself.
And then, after letting the noodles and ingredients settle, I tried it out.
It was actually really fucking good; certainly better than anything I've had in terms of instant noodles.
It was probably a bit more expensive though.

Not sure if you guys have had this or something similar, but feel free to share.

It's kinda neat, yet absolute sloppa in whatever variation by circumstance of need of base ingredients. Just vary it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
what does a traditional Christmas dinner look like where you're at?
here in Poland it's eaten on Christmas Eve and it doesn't contain any meat because Christmas Eve used to be a fasting day over here. traditionally there's supposed to be 12 dishes, either for 12 months in the year or the 12 apostoles. some of them are special Christmas dishes that most people don't eat year round and some are more commonly eaten. these dishes often include:
>fried carp (aka le bathroom fishe)
>various dishes with pickled herring
>various salads
>borscht with mushroom or sauerkraut filled dumplings
>"greek-style fish"
>Christmas kompot made from dried fruit
>bigos (sauerkraut stew) with mushrooms
>poppy seed roll
>various poppy seed based desserts depending on the region
>gingerbread

Here, 'Christmas dinner's is either on Christmas Eve or on Christmas depending on what is convenient for the family, usually with turkey or ham with sides being served. In my family there is usually two, one with the whole extended family on the Eve, and a smaller one of Christmas with my immediate family.
The content of the meal doesn't matter so much, so long as it is a genuine feast. Something special, rich, and over-the-top as compared to the usual.
The one yesterday was glazed ham and the basics (mash potatoes, gravy, broccoli cheese casserole, pan fried corn) with everything else being brought potluck style.
What I will be serving my immediate family tonight with be roasted lamb chops with rosemary, potatoes au gratin, pan fried brussel sprouts with balsamic glaze, and seared veggies in garlic butter. My mom will be making her cheese-stuffed dinner rolls and chocolate cake. Dad takes care of breakfast.
Last year we were hurting for money, so it was broiled fish with roasted carrots, mashed potatoes, and vegetable pasta. I tried my best that year.

posted on /v/ by mistake earlier.

Today I experimented with adding bread crumbs to the ground beef for my tacos. It was a complete success. The taco meat was tender, moist, and flavorful. I surmised that the bread crumbs would prevent the ground beef from essentially bonding together into a rubbery mass as they cooked. The texture is more akin to what you'd get at a fast food place, something that I am looking for in a taco meat.
Instead of browning the meat in the pan first and then adding the taco powder like the instructions say, I mixed ground beef, taco powder, bread crumbs, and a beef cube in a mixing bowl and then added them to a pan that already had some translucently cooked chopped up onions in the pan.

More pics to follow.

posts.com: Yeast need warm to rise. Like snek it wont move in cold. Snek need warm, yeast need warm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18736080
If you mixed in the yeast, put in the fridge and it didn't rise at all it could be that your fridge is at a very low temperature, you froze it by putting it un the upper compartment or you used dry yeast without activating it. You can:
>1
Take a small piece and put it on warm water or milk and let it rest. If it leavens, you just need to let it sit out, covered and in a cool place for it to rise.
>2
If you left it out of the fridge and it doesn't rise at all, cut it into pieces and mix it into new batches, one at a time. Yeast doesn't 'die out' if left on a freezer but lays dormant instead — but if it's dead, then make other batches.
>3
Make a new batch. Use the failed dough to make pita bread or flour tortillas and eat them through the rest of the week; hummus, guacamole, chopped chicken breast cooked with vegetables and many other options are there to eat with that dough stretched into circles and cooked on a pan at high flame or deep-fried.
>4
Make a loaf, bake it at a low temperature, slice it, bake the pieces at a lower temperature and put the toasted slices in a food processor to get panko/bread crumbs for deep frying. Go crazy making fried onions or something.
As long as the dough doesn't taste like shit or is mouldy, it's still usable.

>>18736080
>the yeast I used was all dead.
unless you cooked it then it's not all dead, it's only mostly dead. It's almost impossible to kill yeast. Take it out of the refrigerator and let it proof at 80F or so (your oven may have a proof setting that does this). What yeasts there are left alive will multiply and eventually the bread will rise just fine, it will just take longer than if they had all been alive and active from the start.

It depends on how much leftover you have. I generally debone and cube my ham. Take the hambone + juices and boil that and then add your pasta to it. The pasta absorbs it and retains the flavor. May take some playing around to get the perfect juice-to-pasta ratio down to a science. After that, I add the cubes ham, Parmesan, and steamed green peas.

There is no definitive answer to this question as everyone's body reacts differently to alcohol. However, what is important to remember is that the percentage of alcohol by volume is only one of the many factors that can contribute to how drunk someone becomes when consuming alcohol. Other factors, such as how quickly the alcohol is consumed, the type of beverage, and a person's body weight, can all play a role in how quickly and how much someone becomes intoxicated. Therefore, it is important to consider a variety of factors when assessing how drunk someone can get.
